Let VVV be a real vector space with a symmetric bilinear form ⟨⋅,⋅⟩\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle⟨⋅,⋅⟩. Then, for any v∈Vv \in Vv∈V with ⟨v,v⟩=1\langle v, v \rangle = 1⟨v,v⟩=1, I have defined the reflection rv ⁣:V→Vr_v \colon V \to Vrv​:V→V orthogonal to vvv by the equation rvw=w−2⟨v,w⟩vr_v w = w - 2 \langle v, w \rangle vrv​w=w−2⟨v,w⟩v.

Here is the Lean code for this orthogonal reflection. I write the vector space VVV as B →₀ ℝ and I write rvr_vrv​ as cs.orthoReflection v, or using the local notation r v.

def orthoReflection (_ : CoxeterSystem M W) (v : B →₀ ℝ) :
    (B →₀ ℝ) →ₗ[ℝ] (B →₀ ℝ) := {
      toFun := fun w ↦ w - (2 * ⟪v, w⟫) • v
      map_add' := by
        intro w₁ w₂
        dsimp
        rw [map_add, mul_add, add_smul]
        abel
      map_smul' := by
        intro μ w
        dsimp
        rw [map_smul, mul_smul_comm, smul_assoc, smul_sub]
    }

local prefix:100 "r" => cs.orthoReflection

I would now like to prove that if there is an integer m≥1m \geq 1m≥1 and two vectors v,v′∈Vv, v' \in Vv,v′∈V with ⟨v,v⟩=⟨v′,v′⟩=1\langle v, v \rangle = \langle v', v' \rangle = 1⟨v,v⟩=⟨v′,v′⟩=1 and ⟨v,v′⟩=−cos⁡(π/m)\langle v, v' \rangle = -\cos(\pi / m)⟨v,v′⟩=−cos(π/m), then (rvrv′)m(r_v r_v')^m(rv​rv′​)m is the identity. Of course, this is intuitively obvious, because rvrv′r_v r_v'rv​rv′​ is just a rotation by the angle 2π/m2 \pi / m2π/m in the axis orthogonal to vvv and v′v'v′. (Note that this intuition is not perfect, because ⟨⋅,⋅⟩\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle⟨⋅,⋅⟩ need not be positive definite.)

My first approach was to try to prove that for all natural numbers kkk,

(rvrv′)k=1V−2(Uk−1(μ))2(v(Bv)+v′(Bv′)+μ(v(Bv′)+v′(Bv)))−U2k−1(μ)(v′(Bv)−v(Bv′)).(r_v r_v')^k = 1_V - 2 (U_{k - 1}(\mu))^2 (v(Bv) + v'(Bv') + \mu (v(Bv') + v'(Bv))) - U_{2k - 1}(\mu) (v'(Bv) - v(Bv')).(rv​rv′​)k=1V​−2(Uk−1​(μ))2(v(Bv)+v′(Bv′)+μ(v(Bv′)+v′(Bv)))−U2k−1​(μ)(v′(Bv)−v(Bv′)).

where μ=−⟨v,v′⟩\mu = - \langle v, v'\rangleμ=−⟨v,v′⟩ and B ⁣:V→V∗B \colon V \to V^*B:V→V∗ is the linear map associated to the bilinear form ⟨⋅,⋅⟩\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle⟨⋅,⋅⟩ (viz. (Bv)w=⟨B(v),w⟩(Bv) w = \langle B(v), w\rangle(Bv)w=⟨B(v),w⟩). Here UUU is the Chebyshev polynomial of the second kind, with U−1=0U_{-1} = 0U−1​=0. This formula ought to be provable by straightforward induction on kkk. So that's what I tried:

/-- The Chebyshev polynomial of the second kind corresponding to the index n - 1. Correctly yields U₋₁ = 0 if n = 0.
-/
@[local simp] private def U_minus_one (R : Type u_1) [CommRing R] (n : ℕ) :=
    U R (n + 1) - 2 * (T R (n + 1))

theorem orthoReflection_mul_orthoReflection_pow_apply {v v' w : B →₀ ℝ} (k : ℕ)
    (hv : ⟪v, v⟫ = 1) (hv' : ⟪v', v'⟫ = 1) : (((r v) * (r v')) ^ k) w =
      w - (2 * (eval (-⟪v, v'⟫) (U_minus_one ℝ k)) ^ 2) •
          (⟪v, w⟫ • v + ⟪v', w⟫ • v' - ⟪v, v'⟫ • (⟪v', w⟫ • v + ⟪v, w⟫ • v'))
      - (eval (-⟪v, v'⟫) (U_minus_one ℝ (2 * k))) • (⟪v', w⟫ • v - ⟪v, w⟫ • v') := by
  induction' k with k ih
  · simp
  · simp only [U_minus_one, eval_sub, eval_mul, eval_ofNat, smul_add] at ih ⊢
    rw [pow_succ, LinearMap.mul_apply, ih, LinearMap.mul_apply]
    simp only [map_sub, map_add, map_smul]
    -- First apply r v' to the right-hand side of the inductive hypothesis, then expand everything.
    simp only [(by tauto : ∀ {x : B →₀ ℝ}, cs.orthoReflection v' x = x - (2 * ⟪v', x⟫) • v')]
    simp only [map_sub, map_add, map_smul]
    -- Then apply r v, then expand everything.
    dsimp [orthoReflection]
    apply sub_eq_zero.mp
    simp only [← mul_smul, add_smul, sub_smul, smul_add, smul_sub]

Now, I have a giant 172-line goal. (This is not an exaggeration.) I would like to be able to rewrite it as (something) • v + (something) • v' + (something) • w = 0, and then prove that each of those coefficients is equal to zero. But there doesn't seem to be any tactic that can do that. Moreover, this seems like the wrong approach anyway just based on how irredeemably messy it is.

I had a few other ideas:

  1. Use the above approach, but use the substitution −⟨v,v′⟩=12(z+1z)- \langle v, v'\rangle = \frac{1}{2}\left(z + \frac{1}{z}\right)−⟨v,v′⟩=21​(z+z1​) to make everything easier to write down and simplify. However, I fear that even so, it's not going to be that simple to expand everything out. There's no ring or ring_nf for vector-valued expressions (as far as I know). Also, zzz would not be a real number, and it would potentially be annoying to complexify the vector space.
  2. Consider the 555-dimensional R[μ]\mathbb{R}[\mu]R[μ]-algebra that encodes the multiplication laws of the linear operators 1,v(Bv),v′(Bv′),v(Bv′),v′(Bv)1, v(Bv), v'(Bv'), v(Bv'), v'(Bv)1,v(Bv),v′(Bv′),v(Bv′),v′(Bv). Maybe doing all the computations in that algebra would be easier. But then I'd have to transfer that computation back into End⁡(V)\operatorname{End}(V)End(V) somehow.
  3. Let

v′′=v′+cos⁡(π/m)vsin⁡(π/m)v'' = \frac{v' + \cos (\pi/m) v}{\sin(\pi / m)}v′′=sin(π/m)v′+cos(π/m)v​

be the (normalized) component of v′v'v′ orthogonal to vvv, and then try to write all the computations using vvv and v′′v''v′′ instead of using vvv and v′v'v′.

Does anyone have any thoughts on what would be easiest?
By the way, the motivation for all this is that I want to define the standard geometric representation of a Coxeter group.

I just realized I was making this more difficult than it needed to be. By linearity, it suffices to show that (rvrv′)mw=w(r_v r_{v'})^m w = w(rv​rv′​)mw=w:

  • when w=vw = vw=v,
  • when w=v′w = v'w=v′, and
  • when ⟨v,w⟩=⟨v′,w⟩=0\langle v, w \rangle = \langle v', w \rangle = 0⟨v,w⟩=⟨v′,w⟩=0.
    The third case is easy because both rvw=rv′w=wr_v w = r_{v'} w = wrv​w=rv′​w=w. This should make things a little simpler. Still, I would appreciate any suggestions for how to make it simpler still.

The two comments I thought as I read your thread were: (1) nobody can help you with your 172 line goal because you didn't post a #mwe and (2) the thought you had about just checking for v,v' and things orthogonal to both.

To check for v and v' it still might be subtle. You'll probably have to deal with the case where they span a line separately, and in the plane case my first instinct is to compute the char poly of the linear map acting on the space and then check that the complex eigenvalues are distinct roots of unity, but there might be a less painful way
Yes, thank you for the advice. Yes, I think it will be necessary to separately treat the case m=1m = 1m=1. I didn't know about Module.reflection; I will definitely use that.
